p.s: Hi community, as a part of my work for the international school project Global Shakespeare, I reasonily did some research and found a very interesting article from a germanGerman newspaper that I want to share.
The article was published in April 2016 by the Thüringer Allgemeine a daily paper in the state of Thüringen.
It deals with how Shakespeare's work came to Germany and the impacts it had.
Therefore the city of Weimar plays a major role for the reception of his work.
Until the 18th century Shakespeare's work was widely unknown in Germany due to a lack of translations available.
From 1762 to 1766 Christoph Martin Wieland, an icon of German classics, published the translation of 22 of ShakespearesShakespeare's drama'sdramas.
But it is known that Goethe and Herder were also interested in Shakespeare's work.
On 8th April 1864 a community of Shakespeare fans was founded in order to celebrate his birth and death.
In the same year the Shakespeare society was born in Weimar, as the oldest literature unification in Germany.

For the 40th anniversary of the Shakespeare society the organisation created the first Shakespeare memorial on the europeanEuropean continent in 1904, that can still be seen in the Ilm parcIlmpark in Weimar.
And still today there is a veriety of modern translations and new perceptions of his work, within the germanGerman literature.
I am convinced that this information helps to understand the germanGerman view on Shakespeare but also to get an overview on the influence of his work and it'sits meaning to literature.
